author: cbc
title: B.C. high school cancels student trip to New York over unpredictable U.S. political climate
text:
A high school in Richmond, B.C. has cancelled a student trip to New York City, citing concerns with political turmoil in the U.S.
R.A. McMath Secondary School had planned to send students and staff to the eastern city this spring.
However, a rise in protests following President Donald Trump's inauguration last month has administrators concerned about sending teens south of the border.
A trip to New York has been cancelled by R.A. McMath Secondary school amid political turmoil in the United States. (SD38)
After "careful" deliberation, travel plans were cancelled this week, said principal Neil Kamide
​Kamide said staff involved in putting the trip together were concerned about the "potential for further protests" posing a danger to students.
"Even under normal conditions, sponsoring student travel is an extremely stressful endeavour for staff — it is a 24/7 role with the staff members tasked with ensuring the safety of all students under their care," Kamide told CBC News.
"As the climate in parts of the U.S. is shifting and events and situations seem to be unfolding quickly, our staff currently feels uncomfortable in both moving forward, as well as waiting to see if the situation changes."
Vancouver Whitecaps fan club cancels U.S. away trips due to Trump travel ban Sweeping travel restrictions cause chaos, upheaval at U.S. airports Kamide said the decision to cancel was made swiftly, in part, to ensure that students and their families could still be refunded for travel expenses.
Protests in NYC On Jan. 21 — the day after Trump's inauguration —  more than a million people took part in the Women's March on Washington from across North America.
In the Big Apple alone, more than 400,000 people turned out to the demonstration, focused on civil liberties, immigration, reproductive rights and intolerance.
Protesters hold up signs during the Women's March along Madison Avenue in New York City on Jan. 21. (EPA/Jason Szenes via CP)
A week later, more protests broke out after Trump signed an executive order barring people from seven Muslim-majority countries from entering the U.S.
Thousands  gathered outside a Terminal 4  at John F. Kennedy International Airport to argue the ban and show support for Muslim and refugee communities.
People gather for a protest at Terminal 4 of the John F. Kennedy (JFK) International Airport after people arriving from Muslim countries were held at the border control as a result of the new immigration policies enacted by President Donald Trump. (EPA/Justin Lane via CP)
Both demonstrations — as well as others — were peaceful, but Kamide said he and his colleagues remain apprehensive about taking students to an American metropolitan city such as New York.
"Thus, it is with sadness, we have chosen to cancel," the principal said.
Kamide did not say if the school was planning to reschedule.
